title: About my project!
text:
I am Rui Wen, a Y2 Psychology student. I am passionate about nature and wildlife conservation! Recently, a Jungle Fowl collided into the window of the multi-purpose hall of my RC, causing its death. The datasets I provide are thus on bird-window collisions in Chicago and Cleveland as well as data from the Herpetological Society of Singapore. Their data consists of reports from citizens on reptile roadkill they find. Through analysing these datasets, I hope to raise awareness on the negative impacts of urbanisation on wildlife and conservation.

knitr::include_graphics("hornbill.jpg")

title: Home
text:
My name is Rui Wen and I am very passionate about wildlife and conservation!
Due to urbanisation, much of Singapore’s forests have been deforested. Only 0.28% of Singapore’s landmass is occupied by orignal, undeforested forests (Yee et al., 2011). This means that many wildlife lose their habitats, forcing them to adapt to our urban landscape. This has led to an increase in wildlife roadkill as these animals lose forest connectivity and have to use our roads instead.
Using data from the Herpetological Society of Singapore’s (HSS) Project Runover, I aim to raise awareness on how wildlife, more specifically reptiles, have lost their lives to vehicle collisions.
This interactive map allows you to see the locations where reptile roadkill have been spotted. Using the slider on the left, you can select the year(s). The blue circles on the map represent the location of the reptile roadkill. Can you spot any reptile roadkill hotspots?
 
Next, you can select the type of reptile and see how many of that reptile have been innocently killed on the roads by year.

text: I am Rui Wen, a Y2 Psychology student. I am passionate about nature and wildlife conservation! Recently, a Jungle Fowl collided into the window of the multi-purpose hall of my RC, causing its death. The datasets I provide are thus on bird-window collisions in Chicago and Cleveland as well as data from the Herpetological Society of Singapore. Their data consists of reports from citizens on reptile roadkill they find. Through analysing these datasets, I hope to raise awareness on the negative impacts of urbanisation on wildlife and conservation.

title: Home
text:
My name is Rui Wen and I am very passionate about wildlife and conservation!
Due to urbanisation, much of Singapore’s forests have been deforested. Only 0.28% of Singapore’s landmass is occupied by orignal, undeforested forests (Yee et al., 2011). This means that many wildlife lose their habitats, forcing them to adapt to our urban landscape. This has led to an increase in wildlife roadkill as these animals lose forest connectivity and have to use our roads instead.
Using data from the Herpetological Society of Singapore’s (HSS) Project Runover, I aim to raise awareness on how wildlife, more specifically reptiles, have lost their lives to vehicle collisions. The dataset contains the date, type of animal killed, species, location (langitude and longitude) and path type the roadkill was found on.
This interactive map allows you to see the locations where reptile roadkill have been spotted. Using the slider on the left, you can select the year(s). The blue circles on the map represent the location of the reptile roadkill. Can you spot any reptile roadkill hotspots?
 
Zooming in, let’s observe the type of reptile most vulnerable to becoming roadkill. According to HSS’ data, snakes are the reptile most reported. This could be because they are so low to the ground, making it difficult for drivers to spot the snakes.

From the data above, it is clear that these reptiles are at the mercy of our roads. The number of roadkill each year is likely to increase as Singapore continues to develop.

title: How Has Urbanisation Affected Wildlife?
text:
My name is Rui Wen and I am very passionate about wildlife and conservation! My favourite animals are snakes and I love exploring nature and getting to see wildlife!


The inspiration for this project came from two sources. The first source was from the Kukri Snake roadkill I saw in Kaeng Krachan, Thailand. I knelt by the roadside as it took it last breath, head injured by a vehicle collision.







 Kukri Snake Roadkill. 


My next source of inspiration came from attending the Death By Man Exhibition by Jasvic Lye. The artist photographed the carcasses of different wildlife that died due to human causes. The exhibition humanises these wildlife through narratives and visuals to raise awareness on the adverse impacts of urbanisation on wildlife.


Learn more about Death by Man here!



My project thus aims to bring to light the adverse impacts urbanisation has had on wildlife through examining data from the Herpetological Society of Singapore’s Project Runover.

title: Analysis of Project Runover Data
text:
Temporal Analysis

To see how roadkill numbers have changed over the years, take a look at this line plot:






As seen in the graph, the number of reptile roadkill has increased exponentially from 2011 to 2023. This shows us that wildlife roadkill is a legitimate and pressing concern.


The low records from 2011 to 2020 is because HSS had not officially launched Project Runover yet. Project Runover was only launched in 2020 which explains the sharp increase from 2020 to 2021.


However, as the project gained traction in 2021, the number of yearly roadkill accidents has steadily increased, emphasising the need for mitigation measures to prevent numbers from climbing.


For this graph, I did not include the year 2024 as data for this year is still being collected and accurate data is not available yet.




Species Analysis

Let’s zoom in to see which types of reptiles are the most affected by roadkill:






As seen in the bar plot, snakes are the most affected by roadkill, followed by frogs and monitor lizards. Reptiles are vulnerable to vehicle collisions because they often crawl onto roads to regulate their body temperature. The high occurrence of snake roadkill could be due to stigma against snakes, motivating drivers to run over them.



Interested to know how roadkill incidents have affected the different reptiles each year? Choose a reptile you’re interested to learn more about!
 


Looking at the time of year may also paint a picture on the factors affecting reptile roadkill.






As seen from the heat map, the month with the highest snake roadkill was from May to June. This period is usually the hottest month in Singapore. As such, there may be increased instances of snakes seeking shade beyond forested areas. Other factors such as mating season may affect the number of reptile roadkill found that month.



Curious about how some of these reptiles look? Take a look at the first 5 reptiles recorded in Project Runover:
 



Spatial Analysis

This interactive map allows you to see the locations where reptile roadkill have been spotted. Using the slider on the left, you can select the year(s). The blue circles on the map represent the location of the reptile roadkill. Can you spot any reptile roadkill hotspots?
 

Ironically, but not surprisingly, some reptile roadkill hotspots are roads near nature reserves and parks. Nature reserves and sparks are rich habitats for biodiversity. Due the disruption of forest connectivity to build these roads, wildlife often use roads to move from one place to another. When driving in these areas, drive slowly and keep a lookout for any wildlife!



Now that we know some reptile roadkill hotspots, we can see what type of paths these incidents usually occur on.







As seen by the graph, a very large majority of reptile roadkill are found on roads. This emphasises the adverse impacts urbanisation, and more specifically, roads have had on wildlife.

Through exploring this data, I hope more people are cognisant of the negative impacts urbanisation has had on wildlife. To take action, you can start by contributing to Project Runover if you see any roadkill, driving slowly and staying alert especially at areas near nature reserves, and feedback to governmental institutions about mitigation measures!


 TOGETHER, WE CAN STOP REPTILE ROADKILL! 



References

Banded Malayan Coral Snake—Calliophis intestinalis. (n.d.). Retrieved 15 April 2024.
Common wolf snake (Lycodon capucinus). (n.d.). Retrieved 15 April 2024.
Dendrelaphis cyanochloris. (2022, September 19). In Wikipedia.
Indochinese Rat Snake—Ptyas korros. (n.d.). Retrieved 15 April 2024.
Oriental Whipsnake (Snakes of the Philippines) · iNaturalist. (n.d.). iNaturalist. Retrieved 15 April 2024.

title: Analysis
text:
yearly_counts <- hss %>% na.omit("hss") %>% filter(year_val != 2024) %>%
  group_by(year_val) %>%
  summarise(Count = n())

# Plotting the data
ggplot(yearly_counts, aes(x = year_val, y = Count)) +
  geom_line(group=1, color="blue") + # Use a line plot
  geom_point(color="red") + # Add points to the line plot
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = yearly_counts$year_val, labels = yearly_counts$year_val) + # Set x-axis breaks and labels
  labs(title="Yearly Roadkill Incidents", x="Year", y="Count") +
  theme_minimal()

library(highcharter)

Registered S3 method overwritten by 'quantmod':
  method            from
  as.zoo.data.frame zoo 

library(dplyr)
library(readr)
library(tidyverse)

hc <- hchart(df, "Box and Whisker Diagram", hcaes(y = df$n, group = df$Which.of.the.following.groups.best.describes.the.roadkill.found. ), color = "#2980b9") %>%
  hc_title(text = "Distribution of Roadkill Counts by Type") %>%
  hc_xAxis(title = list(text = "Type of Roadkill"), categories = df$Which.of.the.following.groups.best.describes.the.roadkill.found.) %>%
  hc_yAxis(title = list(text = "Count of Roadkills")) %>%
  hc_tooltip(pointFormat = "<b>{point.y}</b>")
hc

title: Project Runover
text:
Due to urbanisation, much of Singapore’s forests have been deforested. Only 0.28% of Singapore’s landmass is occupied by orignal, undeforested forests (Yee et al., 2011). This means that many wildlife lose their habitats, forcing them to adapt to our urban landscape. This has led to an increase in wildlife roadkill as these animals lose forest connectivity and have to use our roads instead.


Using data from the Herpetological Society of Singapore’s (HSS) Project Runover, I aim to raise awareness on how wildlife, more specifically reptiles, have lost their lives to vehicle collisions. The dataset contains the date, type of animal killed, species, coordinates of where the roadkill was found and path type the roadkill was found on.


Project RunOver is based on citizen science. Citizen Scientists are encouraged to send in sightings of reptile roadkill, regardless of vehicle type. Project Runover uses data from 2011 to the present day.


In my data cleaning process, I removed empty rows to ensure accuracy. In addition, in the original dataset, some of the locations were not coordinates, but street names. To aid the crafting of data visualisations, I converted these street names into coordinates.


Such data is important as it helps us understand the impacts urbanisation has on wildlife and the mitigation measures we can take. Some of these species may even be endangered, and Project Runover is one of the ways we can ensure the survival of more precious wildife species!


I would like to thank Mr Kannan Raja, Head of the Herpetological Society of Singapore, for giving me access to this dataset. If you would like to learn more about HSS, check out their website here!


References

Yee, A. T. K., Corlett, R. T., Liew, S. C., & Tan, H. T. W. (2011). The vegetation of Singapore ―an updated map.
Raja, K. (2021) Project Runover. Herpetological Society of Singapore. https://herpsocsg.com/2021/12/31/project-runover/
